title: The Merchant's Decision
subtitle: If/Else Branching
description:
# Making Choices with Else

You've learned if statements, but what happens when the condition is false? That's where **else** comes in!

## If/Else Structure

The else block runs when the if condition is false:

```csharp
int gold = 30;
int itemCost = 50;

if (gold >= itemCost)
{
    Console.WriteLine("Purchase successful!");
    gold = gold - itemCost;
}
else
{
    Console.WriteLine("Not enough gold!");
}
```

One of these blocks will ALWAYS run - either if or else.

**Key C# differences from Python:**
- Conditions must be in parentheses `( )`
- Code blocks use curly braces `{ }`
- Statements end with semicolons `;`

## Comparison Operators

C# supports many comparison operators:

```csharp
==  // Equal to
!=  // Not equal to
>   // Greater than
<   // Less than
>=  // Greater than or equal to
<=  // Less than or equal to
```

## Your Quest

Create a merchant system that checks if a player can afford an item:
1. Set player's gold amount
2. Set item cost
3. Use if/else to check if player has enough gold
4. If yes: Print success message and show remaining gold
5. If no: Print how much more gold is needed
hints: The condition should check if playerGold >= itemCost (don't forget parentheses!)
In the if block, calculate remainingGold = playerGold - itemCost
In the else block, calculate goldNeeded = itemCost - playerGold
Make sure both blocks print appropriate messages
Remember: conditions go in ( ), code blocks go in { }, statements end with ;
learningObjectives: Understand if/else branching logic in C#
Use proper C# syntax with parentheses and braces
Create programs that respond to different situations
